stem: A client is receiving a unit of PRBCs that has been hanging at the bedside for 3.5 hours. Suddenly, he develops a temperature of 105.4°F and shaking chills (rigors). Based on the documentation in the Post-Transfusion Fever & Culture Surveillance Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Extreme hyperpyrexia and shock during blood transfusion.
Background: Sepsis rule-out. Blood hung late in the shift.
Assessment: Client is shivering violently. BP has dropped from 120/80 to 86/42.
Recommendation: Immediate stop and culture of the bag.

tabs.title: Fever & Culture Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemResultHemolytic PatternSeptic Pattern
Core Temp105.4°F (Extreme)High FeverExtremely High (Spike)
Urine ColorClear / YellowDark / Cola (Hemoglobinuria)Clear
Shock TypeDistributive (Septic)Hypovolemic/DistributiveSeptic Shock
Hang Time3.5 - 4 hoursImpacted by timingHigh risk for bacterial growth

actionOptions.text: Stop the transfusion and disconnect the tubing from the IV hub
Send the remaining blood bag and tubing to the lab/blood bank for culture
Flush the remaining blood in the line with 50 mL of D5W
Apply heating blankets to stop the shivering/rigors

parameterOptions.text: Blood pressure, MAP, and core temperature monitoring
Urine output and clarity (Monitoring for renal shutdown)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a Septic Transfusion Reaction (c2). Bacterial contamination (often by Gram-negative bacteria) in a blood bag can cause catastrophic shock and extreme fever (105+). The giveaway is the extreme fever spike and rigors WITHOUT hemoglobinuria (which would point to hemolytic). Priority actions are stopping the 'source' (a1) and culturing the bag (a2) to identify the pathogen. Monitoring focuses on the resulting septic shock (p1) and renal clearance (p2).
clinicalPearls: Blood must be infused within 4 hours. If it hangs longer, the risk for bacterial growth spikes.
In a septic reaction, the symptoms can start immediately or up to several hours after the transfusion ends.
The fever in a septic reaction is usually 2+ degrees higher than the baseline, often accompanied by vomiting/diarrhea.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the urine and the severity. Hemolytic reactions cause flank pain and dark urine. Septic reactions cause 105+ fever, RIGORS (shaking), and crashing blood pressure.

mnemonic.title: Septic Shakes
mnemonic.expansion: S-Spiking Temp (105). H-Hypotension. A-Always culture bag. K-Keep away from patient (Stop). E-Extreme chills.
